channel.title: Chemistry help.. double replacement/displacement
channel.description:
I need to do some (36) equations.. can you help me with this one. and tell me how you did it?
NiCl[size=6pt]2[/size] + Na[size=6pt]2[/size]CO[size=6pt]3[/size] --> ??? + ???
This method is supposed to be used. AB + CD --> AC + BD
The only other problem is the oxidation numbers, and i have to look up each one and it's so friggen confusing!!! :(
Please help. Thanks..
~Ron

item.title: Chemistry help.. double replacement/displacement
item.dc:creator: @_Vengeance _Vengeance
item.description:
@_Vengeance wrote:

Nice 2 year bump.
In case for whatever reason you still need helpâ€¦

NiCl2 + Na2CO3 --> NiCO3 + 2NaCl

Read full topic

item.title: Chemistry help.. double replacement/displacement
item.dc:creator: @Ron Ron
item.description:
@Ron wrote:

-CJT-:

Lol grats! Yeah, chemistry isn't my thing. I just began chemistry class and want to die.

Thanks man! Chemistry isn't that bad though. Just like what jme said...

jme_009:

But at least its fun when you start mixing chemicals together.

It really is fun when you start mixing chemicals, balancing equations (math), and doing labs and mini labs.

Read full topic

item.title: Chemistry help.. double replacement/displacement
item.dc:creator: @jme jme
item.description:
@jme wrote:

But at least its fun when you start mixing chemicals together.

My teacher mixed some pottasium and water, except she used too much pottassium. The results were cool, but really dangerous consiering the beaker blew up into a million pieces, and acid rained on all of us, and my friend still has a scar from that glass that went into his hand. Oh yeah and not to mention the layer of smoke for 5 minutes. When we opened the door the fire alarm went off Fun stuff And of course burning things with the bunsen burners are fun. We loaded up a crapload of powdered magnesium and it made a huge ass white fire ball(There was seriously A LOT of magnesium powder).

Read full topic

item.title: Chemistry help.. double replacement/displacement
item.dc:creator: @Ron Ron
item.description:
@Ron wrote:

Took my chem retest today.

Ron: Yes! Finally Finished!
Teacher: Alright calm down, just bring it up.
Ron: okay
Teacher: If you wait, I can grade it now and tell you what you got.
Ron: alright
Teacher: My...my... my
Ron: uh oh...
Teacher: Did you study for this exam?
Ron: Yeah I did, all night.
Teacher: Good, you got a 98.
Ron: nice

(I let it soak in and then I was like YES YESSSS!!!!) a 98 is so much better than a 58 lol

~Ron

Read full topic

item.title: Chemistry help.. double replacement/displacement
item.dc:creator: @Ron Ron
item.description:
@Ron wrote:

Ni is nickel. Nitrogen is N.

Yeah that isn't right lol. For one thing I screwed up the method... it's Ax + By --> Ay + Bx.

Plus now the teacher wants states of matter too. Aquious, Precipatate, gas, solid, liquid... GRRR Sophomore testing tomorrow, tons of work in accounting, spanish, chem, and american studies. Plus a retest tomorrow on chemistry on this stupid shit...

[size=6]Ahhhhhhhh!!!!!!![/size]

Thanks for trying to help though.

Read full topic

item.title: Chemistry help.. double replacement/displacement
item.dc:creator: @jme jme
item.description:
@jme wrote:

Ron:

I need to do some (36) equations.. can you help me with this one. and tell me how you did it?

NiCl[size=6pt]2[/size] + Na[size=6pt]2[/size]CO[size=6pt]3[/size] --> ??? + ???

This method is supposed to be used. AB + CD --> AC + BD

The only other problem is the oxidation numbers, and i have to look up each one and it's so friggen confusing!!!

Please help. Thanks..

~Ron

I only did grade 10 science, and I only got in the 70's so dont qoute me on this, but I think its:
Ni2Na + Cl3+CO2 (Note, electrons switch places I think).

I forget most of this, so I'm probably wrong. I forget the charges of all the elements and stuff, and I can't really explain this eqation other then:

If it's AB + CD --> AC + BD then
A= Ni
B = Cl2
C= Na2
D = CO3

Dont forget that when they mix, they switch their charges around:
Example:
Berrylium has a charge of 2
Carbon has a charge of 4 (I think?)
So that would be Be2 + C4 --> Be4C2

Btw, what is Ni?? Nitrogen? I thought nitrogen was just N
I feel like a retard right now, it's been a while.

Read full topic
